Energy security is built in to the InnoEnergy portfolio. Take Holosolis, a start-up poised to build the biggest PV module gigafactory in Europe. Holosolis addresses the issue of imbalance in the solar industry, with China currently responsible for 80% of the world’s installed photovoltaic modules. Christian Comes, Director of Business Development Europe, Huasun Energy, at the TaiyangNews - All About Solar Special Webinar on HJT Technology Updates and Market Opportunities in Europe, focused on how HJT PV plants achieve the lowest cost of energy. He went into the details of LCOE calculations. Talking about linking efficiency and CAPEX, Comes stressed that there is a need for fair and realistic system configurations, and batted for equivalent saving due to higher or lower performance. He emphasized on how HJT saves balance of system cost (BoS). In support of the Japan-U.S.-Mekong Power Partnership and with funding from the U.S. Department of State - Bureau of Energy Resources Power Sector Program, NARUC met with the Electricity Authority of Cambodia (EAC) and other energy sector stakeholders to share knowledge that will help the EAC develop a robust regulatory framework for the development of renewable distributed energy resources projects (DERs), particularly rooftop solar photovoltaics. Additionally, discussions focused on considerations for promoting electric vehicle (EV) usage in Cambodia, including options for managing and pricing EV charging stations. As a result, participants will be better equipped to increase the integration of DERs while maintaining grid reliability and resiliency. #Cambodia #electricity #energysector #rooftopsolar #electricvehicles

It is time to develop a new way of rating these installations. The article says the installation is 540MW, the nameplate capacity, but the important figure would be the amount of power sent to the grid. The article says this installation dispatched 30MW more than the old coal facility. Still, the dispatch is not over a full 24-hour period. In contrast, the coal facility would operate on a 24-hour basis, so the deliverable power from the solar installation might not be more than what the coal plant delivers. I think we need standardization of how we report or quantify the amount of power delivered from these installations.
